item.title: Defining Services
item.description: Using a dependency injection container is beneficial for bootstrapping Backslash applications. The number of components and their dependencies makes a container practical for managing instantiation and wiring.

item.title: Extending with Middleware
item.description: Middleware provides a powerful way to add cross-cutting concerns to Backslash components. It follows an onion layer model, allowing logic to be executed before and after core operations.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Backslash is a modern and opinionated PHP library for building event-sourced applications with CQRS. It is fully compliant with the Dynamic Consistency Boundary specification.

item.title: Rebuilding Projections
item.description: Rebuilding projections is a routine task in event-sourced applications. This capability allows you to reconstruct read models from scratch by replaying the complete event history.

item.title: Setting Up Tests
item.description: Testing event-sourced applications requires specific infrastructure setup. This section shows how to configure PHPUnit and create a base test case for your Backslash application.

item.title: Understanding CQRS
item.description: Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) is a pattern that separates read and write operations into distinct models. Instead of using the same model for both updates and queries, CQRS uses different models optimized for their specific purposes.

item.title: Architecture Overview
item.description: Backslash is designed around the core principles of event sourcing and CQRS. Its modular, lightweight, and framework-agnostic architecture allows for gradual adoption or integration into existing systems.

item.title: Dispatching Commands
item.description: Commands represent intentions to change the system’s state. Unlike events that describe what happened, commands express what should happen. They carry the information needed to make a business decision and are the entry points for all write operations.

item.title: Enriching Event Streams
item.description: Event stream enrichment allows applications to inject metadata into events as they flow through the system. This metadata provides contextual information like the current tenant, authenticated user, or correlation keys.

item.title: Registering Handlers
item.description: The boot process registers commands with the dispatcher and events with the event bus, establishing the routing between messages and their handlers. This registration happens after service definitions are loaded but before the application handles any requests or executes commands.
